Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine that day by day, your field of vision 
becomes slightly smaller, narrowing or dimming until eventually you go completely blind. We tend to think of blindness
as something you're born with, but in fact, with many diseases
like Retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome, blindness can start developing
when you're a kid, or even when you're an adult. Both of these rare genetic diseases
affect the retina, the screen at the back of the eye
that detects light and helps us see. Now imagine if the eye 
could regenerate itself so that a blind person could see again. To understand if that's possible,
we need to grasp how the retina works and what it has to do 
with a multitalented creature named the zebrafish. The human retina is made
of different layers of cells, with special neurons 
that live in the back of the eye called rod and cone photoreceptors. Photoreceptors convert 
the light coming into your eye into signals that the brain uses 
to generate vision. People who have Usher syndrome
and retinitis pigmentosa experience a steady loss 
of these photoreceptors until finally that screen in the eye
can no longer detect light nor broadcast signals to the brain. Unlike most of your body's cells,
photoreceptors don't divide and multiply. We're born with all 
the photoreceptors we'll ever have, which is why babies 
have such big eyes for their faces and part of why they're so cute. But that isn't the case for all animals. Take the zebrafish,
a master regenerator. It can grow back its skin, bones, heart
and retina after they've been damaged. If photoreceptors in the zebrafish retina
are removed or killed by toxins, they just regenerate and rewire 
themselves to the brain to restore sight. Scientists have been investigating
this superpower because zebrafish retina are also 
structured very much like human retina. Scientists can even mimic the effects
of disorders like Usher syndrome or retinitis pigmentosa
on the zebrafish eye. This allows them to see how zebrafish
go about repairing their retinas so they might use similar tactics
to fix human eyes one day, too. So what's behind 
the zebrafish's superpower? The main players are sets of long cells
that stretch across the retina called Müller glia. When the photoreceptors are damaged,
these cells transform, taking on a new character. They become less like Müller cells
and more like stem cells, which can turn into any kind of cell. Then these long cells divide, producing extras that will eventually
grow into new photoreceptors, travel to the back of the eye
and rewire themselves into the brain. And now some researchers even think
they've found the key to how this works with the help of one of two chemicals
that create activity in the brain called glutamate
and aminoadipate. In mouse eyes, these make the Müller glia divide
and transform into photoreceptors, which then travel 
to the back of the retina, like they're replenishing a failing army
with new soldiers. But remember, none of this has happened
in our retinas yet, so the question is how do we trigger 
this transformation of the Müller glia in the human eye? How can we fully control this process? How do photoreceptors 
rewire themselves into the retina? And is it even possible 
to trigger this in humans? Or has this mechanism been lost
over time in evolution? Until we tease apart 
the origins of this ability, retinal regeneration will remain 
a mysterious superpower of the common zebrafish.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The cells in the retina that detect light are called:
Options: A. Muller cells, B. Neuronal cells, C. Photoreceptor cells, D. Zebrafish cells
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary effect of diseases like Retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome on the human eye? Options: A. The eye becomes more sensitive to light, B. The eye changes color, C. The retina degenerates, leading to blindness, D. The eye becomes more resistant to disease Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the function of photoreceptors in the human retina? Options: A. To detect sound waves, B. To convert light into signals for the brain, C. To produce tears, D. To control eye movement Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is unique about the way photoreceptors in the human eye develop? Options: A. They can divide and multiply throughout life, B. They are only present in the peripheral vision, C. We are born with all the photoreceptors we will ever have, D. They can change color Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which animal is known for its ability to regenerate its retina? Options: A. Mouse, B. Zebrafish, C. Human, D. Snake Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the role of Müller glia in the zebrafish's retinal regeneration? Options: A. They produce toxins that damage the retina, B. They transform into stem cells and produce new photoreceptors, C. They control eye movement, D. They detect light Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the potential benefit of studying the zebrafish's retinal regeneration? Options: A. Understanding how to slow down retinal degeneration, B. Understanding how to regenerate human retinas, C. Understanding how to improve peripheral vision, D. Understanding how to change eye color Correct Option: None
Question 7: Which chemicals have been found to trigger the transformation of Müller glia into photoreceptors in mouse eyes? Options: A. Glutamate and aminoadipate, B. Retinol and vitamin A, C. Calcium and potassium, D. Sodium and chloride Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the main challenge in applying the zebrafish's retinal regeneration mechanism to humans? Options: A. Understanding how to slow down retinal degeneration, B. Understanding how to trigger the transformation of Müller glia in the human eye, C. Understanding how to improve peripheral vision, D. Understanding how to change eye color Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why is the zebrafish a useful model for studying retinal regeneration? Options: A. Its retina is structured very differently from the human retina, B. Its retina is structured very similarly to the human retina, C. It has a short lifespan, D. It has a large brain Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the current state of retinal regeneration in humans? Options: A. It is a proven and widely used treatment for retinal degeneration, B. It is a promising area of research, but not yet possible in humans, C. It is only possible in certain cases of retinal degeneration, D. It is not possible and will never be possible Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: What is the function of photoreceptors in the human retina? Options: A. To detect sound waves, B. To convert light into signals for the brain, C. To produce tears, D. To control eye movement.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying the function of photoreceptors) and options (the correct option, B, is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, C. Photoreceptor cells). The content of the question is also similar, as both questions are asking about the role of photoreceptors in the human retina.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine that day by day, your field of vision 
becomes slightly smaller, narrowing or dimming until eventually you go completely blind. We tend to think of blindness
as something you're born with, but in fact, with many diseases
like Retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome, blindness can start developing
when you're a kid, or even when you're an adult. Both of these rare genetic diseases
affect the retina, the screen at the back of the eye
that detects light and helps us see. Now imagine if the eye 
could regenerate itself so that a blind person could see again. To understand if that's possible,
we need to grasp how the retina works and what it has to do 
with a multitalented creature named the zebrafish. The human retina is made
of different layers of cells, with special neurons 
that live in the back of the eye called rod and cone photoreceptors. Photoreceptors convert 
the light coming into your eye into signals that the brain uses 
to generate vision. People who have Usher syndrome
and retinitis pigmentosa experience a steady loss 
of these photoreceptors until finally that screen in the eye
can no longer detect light nor broadcast signals to the brain. Unlike most of your body's cells,
photoreceptors don't divide and multiply. We're born with all 
the photoreceptors we'll ever have, which is why babies 
have such big eyes for their faces and part of why they're so cute. But that isn't the case for all animals. Take the zebrafish,
a master regenerator. It can grow back its skin, bones, heart
and retina after they've been damaged. If photoreceptors in the zebrafish retina
are removed or killed by toxins, they just regenerate and rewire 
themselves to the brain to restore sight. Scientists have been investigating
this superpower because zebrafish retina are also 
structured very much like human retina. Scientists can even mimic the effects
of disorders like Usher syndrome or retinitis pigmentosa
on the zebrafish eye. This allows them to see how zebrafish
go about repairing their retinas so they might use similar tactics
to fix human eyes one day, too. So what's behind 
the zebrafish's superpower? The main players are sets of long cells
that stretch across the retina called Müller glia. When the photoreceptors are damaged,
these cells transform, taking on a new character. They become less like Müller cells
and more like stem cells, which can turn into any kind of cell. Then these long cells divide, producing extras that will eventually
grow into new photoreceptors, travel to the back of the eye
and rewire themselves into the brain. And now some researchers even think
they've found the key to how this works with the help of one of two chemicals
that create activity in the brain called glutamate
and aminoadipate. In mouse eyes, these make the Müller glia divide
and transform into photoreceptors, which then travel 
to the back of the retina, like they're replenishing a failing army
with new soldiers. But remember, none of this has happened
in our retinas yet, so the question is how do we trigger 
this transformation of the Müller glia in the human eye? How can we fully control this process? How do photoreceptors 
rewire themselves into the retina? And is it even possible 
to trigger this in humans? Or has this mechanism been lost
over time in evolution? Until we tease apart 
the origins of this ability, retinal regeneration will remain 
a mysterious superpower of the common zebrafish.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Before they divide, Muller cells transform to become more like:
Options: A. Stem cells, B. Photoreceptor cells, C. Neuronal cells, D. Glial cells
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary effect of diseases like Retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome on the human eye? Options: A. The eye becomes more sensitive to light, B. The eye changes color, C. The retina degenerates, leading to blindness, D. The eye becomes more resistant to disease Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the function of photoreceptors in the human retina? Options: A. To detect sound waves, B. To convert light into signals for the brain, C. To produce tears, D. To control eye movement Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is unique about the way photoreceptors in the human eye develop? Options: A. They can divide and multiply throughout life, B. They are only present in the peripheral vision, C. We are born with all the photoreceptors we will ever have, D. They can change color Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which animal is known for its ability to regenerate its retina? Options: A. Mouse, B. Zebrafish, C. Human, D. Snake Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the role of Müller glia in the zebrafish's retinal regeneration? Options: A. They produce toxins that damage the retina, B. They transform into stem cells and produce new photoreceptors, C. They control eye movement, D. They detect light Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the potential benefit of studying the zebrafish's retinal regeneration? Options: A. Understanding how to slow down retinal degeneration, B. Understanding how to regenerate human retinas, C. Understanding how to improve peripheral vision, D. Understanding how to change eye color Correct Option: None
Question 7: Which chemicals have been found to trigger the transformation of Müller glia into photoreceptors in mouse eyes? Options: A. Glutamate and aminoadipate, B. Retinol and vitamin A, C. Calcium and potassium, D. Sodium and chloride Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the main challenge in applying the zebrafish's retinal regeneration mechanism to humans? Options: A. Understanding how to slow down retinal degeneration, B. Understanding how to trigger the transformation of Müller glia in the human eye, C. Understanding how to improve peripheral vision, D. Understanding how to change eye color Correct Option: None
Question 9: Why is the zebrafish a useful model for studying retinal regeneration? Options: A. Its retina is structured very differently from the human retina, B. Its retina is structured very similarly to the human retina, C. It has a short lifespan, D. It has a large brain Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the current state of retinal regeneration in humans? Options: A. It is a proven and widely used treatment for retinal degeneration, B. It is a promising area of research, but not yet possible in humans, C. It is only possible in certain cases of retinal degeneration, D. It is not possible and will never be possible Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What is the role of Müller glia in the zebrafish's retinal regeneration? 

Although the question is not an exact match, the correct option (B) in Question 5 mentions that Müller glia "transform into stem cells and produce new photoreceptors", which aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about the transformation of Müller cells before they divide, and the correct option is "stem cells". 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine that day by day, your field of vision 
becomes slightly smaller, narrowing or dimming until eventually you go completely blind. We tend to think of blindness
as something you're born with, but in fact, with many diseases
like Retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome, blindness can start developing
when you're a kid, or even when you're an adult. Both of these rare genetic diseases
affect the retina, the screen at the back of the eye
that detects light and helps us see. Now imagine if the eye 
could regenerate itself so that a blind person could see again. To understand if that's possible,
we need to grasp how the retina works and what it has to do 
with a multitalented creature named the zebrafish. The human retina is made
of different layers of cells, with special neurons 
that live in the back of the eye called rod and cone photoreceptors. Photoreceptors convert 
the light coming into your eye into signals that the brain uses 
to generate vision. People who have Usher syndrome
and retinitis pigmentosa experience a steady loss 
of these photoreceptors until finally that screen in the eye
can no longer detect light nor broadcast signals to the brain. Unlike most of your body's cells,
photoreceptors don't divide and multiply. We're born with all 
the photoreceptors we'll ever have, which is why babies 
have such big eyes for their faces and part of why they're so cute. But that isn't the case for all animals. Take the zebrafish,
a master regenerator. It can grow back its skin, bones, heart
and retina after they've been damaged. If photoreceptors in the zebrafish retina
are removed or killed by toxins, they just regenerate and rewire 
themselves to the brain to restore sight. Scientists have been investigating
this superpower because zebrafish retina are also 
structured very much like human retina. Scientists can even mimic the effects
of disorders like Usher syndrome or retinitis pigmentosa
on the zebrafish eye. This allows them to see how zebrafish
go about repairing their retinas so they might use similar tactics
to fix human eyes one day, too. So what's behind 
the zebrafish's superpower? The main players are sets of long cells
that stretch across the retina called Müller glia. When the photoreceptors are damaged,
these cells transform, taking on a new character. They become less like Müller cells
and more like stem cells, which can turn into any kind of cell. Then these long cells divide, producing extras that will eventually
grow into new photoreceptors, travel to the back of the eye
and rewire themselves into the brain. And now some researchers even think
they've found the key to how this works with the help of one of two chemicals
that create activity in the brain called glutamate
and aminoadipate. In mouse eyes, these make the Müller glia divide
and transform into photoreceptors, which then travel 
to the back of the retina, like they're replenishing a failing army
with new soldiers. But remember, none of this has happened
in our retinas yet, so the question is how do we trigger 
this transformation of the Müller glia in the human eye? How can we fully control this process? How do photoreceptors 
rewire themselves into the retina? And is it even possible 
to trigger this in humans? Or has this mechanism been lost
over time in evolution? Until we tease apart 
the origins of this ability, retinal regeneration will remain 
a mysterious superpower of the common zebrafish.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Aminoadipate and glutamate make Muller glia:
Options: A. Become more like stem cells, B. Divide, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary effect of diseases like Retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome on the human eye? Options: A. The eye becomes more sensitive to light, B. The eye changes color, C. The retina degenerates, leading to blindness, D. The eye becomes more resistant to disease Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the function of photoreceptors in the human retina? Options: A. To detect sound waves, B. To convert light into signals for the brain, C. To produce tears, D. To control eye movement Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is unique about the way photoreceptors in the human eye develop? Options: A. They can divide and multiply throughout life, B. They are only present in the peripheral vision, C. We are born with all the photoreceptors we will ever have, D. They can change color Correct Option: None

Understanding how to regenerate human retinas, C. Understanding how to improve peripheral vision, D. Understanding how to change eye color Correct Option: None

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: Which chemicals have been found to trigger the transformation of Müller glia into photoreceptors in mouse eyes? Options: A. Glutamate and aminoadipate, B. Retinol and vitamin A, C. Calcium and potassium, D. Sodium and chloride.

However, the options in Question 7 do not exactly match the options in the ground truth MCQ. A more similar question would be one that asks about the effect of aminoadipate and glutamate on Müller glia.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You probably don't need to be told 
how important your brain is. After all, every single thing 
you experience, your thoughts and your actions, your perceptions and your memories are processed here 
in your body's control center. But if this already seems like a lot
for a single organ to handle, it's actually only a small 
part of what the brain does. Most of its activities are ones 
you'd never be aware of, unless they suddenly stopped. The brain is made up 
of billions of neurons, and trillions of connections. Neurons can be activated 
by specific stimuli or thoughts, but they are also often 
spontaneously active. Some fire cyclically in a set pattern. Others fire rapidly in short bursts 
before switching off, or remain quiet for long periods until thousands of inputs from other 
neurons line up in just the right way. On a large scale, this results in elaborate rhythms 
of internally generated brain activity, humming quietly in the background whether we're awake, asleep, or trying not to think 
about anything at all. And these spontaneously 
occurring brain functions form the foundation upon which
all other brain functions rely. The most crucial of these automatically
occurring activities are the ones that keep us alive. For example, while you've been
paying attention to this video spontaneous activity in your brain
has been maintaining your breathing at 12 to 16 breaths a minute,
making sure that you don't suffocate. Without any conscious effort, signals from parts of your brainstem
are sent through the spinal cord to the muscles that inflate your lungs, making them expand and contract,
whether or not you're paying attention. The neuronal circuits underlying such 
rhythmic spontaneous activity are called central pattern generators, and control many 
simple repetitive behaviors, like breathing, walking, and swallowing. Ongoing neural activity also underlies
our sensory perception. It may seem that the neurons in your retina
that translate light into neural signals would remain quiet in the dark, but in fact, the retinal ganglion cells 
that communicate with the brain are always active. And the signals they send are increases 
and decreases in the rate of activity, rather than separate bursts. So at every level, our nervous system
is teeming with spontaneous activity that helps it interpret and respond
to any signals it might receive. And our brain's autopilot isn't just 
limited to our basic biological functions. Have you ever been on the way home, started thinking 
about what's for dinner, and then realized you don't remember
walking for the past five minutes? While we don't understand all the details, we do know that the ongoing activity
in multiple parts of your brain is somehow able to coordinate 
what is actually a complex task involving both cognitive 
and motor functions, guiding you down the right path
and moving your legs while you're getting dinner figured out. But perhaps the most interesting thing
about spontaneous brain function is its involvement in one 
of the most mysterious and poorly understood phenomena
of our bodies: sleep. You may shut down 
and become inactive at night, but your brain doesn't. While you sleep, ongoing spontaneous activity gradually 
becomes more and more synchronized, eventually developing into large, 
rhythmic neural oscillations that envelop your brain. This transition to the more 
organized rhythms of sleep starts with small clusters of neurons
tucked in the hypothalamus. Despite their small number, these neurons have a huge effect in turning off brainstem regions
that normally keep you awake and alert, letting other parts, 
like the cortex and thalamus, slowly slip into their 
own default rhythms. The deeper we fall into sleep, the slower and more synchronized
this rhythm becomes, with the deepest stages dominated by large
amplitude, low frequency delta waves. But surprisingly, in the middle 
of this slow wave sleep, the brain's synchronized 
spontaneous activity repeatedly transitions
into the sort of varied bursts that occur when we're wide awake. This is the sleep stage
known as REM sleep, where our eyes move rapidly 
back and forth as we dream. Neuroscientists are still trying to answer
many fundamental questions about sleep, such as its role in rejuvenating
cognitive capacity, cellular homeostasis, and strengthening memory. And more broadly, they are exploring how it is that brain can accomplish 
such important and complex tasks, such as driving, or even breathing,
without our awareness. But for now, until we are better able to understand the inner workings
of their spontaneous functioning, we need to give our brains credit
for being much smarter than we ourselves are.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The brain is made up of _____
Options: A. Dozens of neurons, B. Thousands of neurons, C. Millions of neurons, D. Billions of neurons
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the brain's primary function in the human body? Options: A. To control the heart rate, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To serve as the body's control center, D. To facilitate digestion Correct Option: None
Question 2: What are the building blocks of the brain? Options: A. Muscles, B. Neurons, C. Bones, D. Nerves Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of brain activity occurs without conscious effort? Options: A. Voluntary activity, B. Spontaneous activity, C. Controlled activity, D. Regulated activity Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the function of central pattern generators in the brain? Options: A. To control complex behaviors, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To facilitate sensory perception, D. To control simple repetitive behaviors Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is an example of a simple repetitive behavior controlled by central pattern generators? Options: A. Reading, B. Writing, C. Breathing, D. Problem-solving Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the role of ongoing neural activity in sensory perception? Options: A. To translate light into neural signals, B. To facilitate hearing, C. To interpret and respond to signals, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is an example of the brain's autopilot function in everyday life? Options: A. Solving complex math problems, B. Walking home without conscious attention, C. Reading a book, D. Writing a letter Correct Option: None
Question 8: What happens to spontaneous brain activity during sleep? Options: A. It becomes more random and disorganized, B. It becomes more synchronized and rhythmic, C. It remains the same as during wakefulness, D. It stops completely Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the stage of sleep characterized by rapid eye movements and varied bursts of brain activity? Options: A. Non-REM sleep, B. REM sleep, C. Deep sleep, D. Light sleep Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is one of the fundamental questions about sleep that neuroscientists are still trying to answer? Options: A. What is the role of sleep in rejuvenating cognitive capacity?, B. How does the brain control body temperature?, C. What is the function of the heart?, D. How does the brain facilitate digestion? Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: What are the building blocks of the brain? Options: A. Muscles, B. Neurons, C. Bones, D. Nerves.

Although the options in the generated MCQ do not exactly match the options in the ground truth MCQ, the question intent and content are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks about the number of neurons in the brain, while the generated MCQ asks about the building blocks of the brain, which are indeed neurons.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You probably don't need to be told 
how important your brain is. After all, every single thing 
you experience, your thoughts and your actions, your perceptions and your memories are processed here

of their spontaneous functioning, we need to give our brains credit
for being much smarter than we ourselves are.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following rely on spontaenous neuronal activity?
Options: A. Breathing, B. Walking, C. Seeing, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the brain's primary function in the human body? Options: A. To control the heart rate, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To serve as the body's control center, D. To facilitate digestion Correct Option: None
Question 2: What are the building blocks of the brain? Options: A. Muscles, B. Neurons, C. Bones, D. Nerves Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of brain activity occurs without conscious effort? Options: A. Voluntary activity, B. Spontaneous activity, C. Controlled activity, D. Regulated activity Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the function of central pattern generators in the brain? Options: A. To control complex behaviors, B. To regulate body temperature, C. To facilitate sensory perception, D. To control simple repetitive behaviors Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is an example of a simple repetitive behavior controlled by central pattern generators? Options: A. Reading, B. Writing, C. Breathing, D. Problem-solving Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the role of ongoing neural activity in sensory perception? Options: A. To translate light into neural signals, B. To facilitate hearing, C. To interpret and respond to signals, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is an example of the brain's autopilot function in everyday life? Options: A. Solving complex math problems, B. Walking home without conscious attention, C. Reading a book, D. Writing a letter Correct Option: None
Question 8: What happens to spontaneous brain activity during sleep? Options: A. It becomes more random and disorganized, B. It becomes more synchronized and rhythmic, C. It remains the same as during wakefulness, D. It stops completely Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You probably don't need to be told 
how important your brain is. After all, every single thing 
you experience, your thoughts and your actions, your perceptions and your memories are processed here 
in your body's control center. But if this already seems like a lot
for a single organ to handle, it's actually only a small 
part of what the brain does. Most of its activities are ones 
you'd never be aware of, unless they suddenly stopped. The brain is made up 
of billions of neurons, and trillions of connections. Neurons can be activated 
by specific stimuli or thoughts, but they are also often 
spontaneously active. Some fire cyclically in a set pattern. Others fire rapidly in short bursts 
before switching off, or remain quiet for long periods until thousands of inputs from other 
neurons line up in just the right way. On a large scale, this results in elaborate rhythms 
of internally generated brain activity, humming quietly in the background whether we're awake, asleep, or trying not to think 
about anything at all. And these spontaneously 
occurring brain functions form the foundation upon which
all other brain functions rely. The most crucial of these automatically
occurring activities are the ones that keep us alive. For example, while you've been
paying attention to this video spontaneous activity in your brain
has been maintaining your breathing at 12 to 16 breaths a minute,
making sure that you don't suffocate. Without any conscious effort, signals from parts of your brainstem
are sent through the spinal cord to the muscles that inflate your lungs, making them expand and contract,
whether or not you're paying attention. The neuronal circuits underlying such 
rhythmic spontaneous activity are called central pattern generators, and control many 
simple repetitive behaviors, like breathing, walking, and swallowing. Ongoing neural activity also underlies
our sensory perception. It may seem that the neurons in your retina
that translate light into neural signals would remain quiet in the dark, but in fact, the retinal ganglion cells 
that communicate with the brain are always active. And the signals they send are increases 
and decreases in the rate of activity, rather than separate bursts. So at every level, our nervous system
is teeming with spontaneous activity that helps it interpret and respond
to any signals it might receive. And our brain's autopilot isn't just 
limited to our basic biological functions. Have you ever been on the way home, started thinking 
about what's for dinner, and then realized you don't remember
walking for the past five minutes? While we don't understand all the details, we do know that the ongoing activity
in multiple parts of your brain is somehow able to coordinate 
what is actually a complex task involving both cognitive 
and motor functions, guiding you down the right path
and moving your legs while you're getting dinner figured out. But perhaps the most interesting thing
about spontaneous brain function is its involvement in one 
of the most mysterious and poorly understood phenomena
of our bodies: sleep. You may shut down 
and become inactive at night, but your brain doesn't. While you sleep, ongoing spontaneous activity gradually 
becomes more and more synchronized, eventually developing into large, 
rhythmic neural oscillations that envelop your brain. This transition to the more 
organized rhythms of sleep starts with small clusters of neurons
tucked in the hypothalamus. Despite their small number, these neurons have a huge effect in turning off brainstem regions
that normally keep you awake and alert, letting other parts, 
like the cortex and thalamus, slowly slip into their 
own default rhythms. The deeper we fall into sleep, the slower and more synchronized
this rhythm becomes, with the deepest stages dominated by large
amplitude, low frequency delta waves. But surprisingly, in the middle 
of this slow wave sleep, the brain's synchronized 
spontaneous activity repeatedly transitions
into the sort of varied bursts that occur when we're wide awake. This is the sleep stage
known as REM sleep, where our eyes move rapidly 
back and forth as we dream. Neuroscientists are still trying to answer
many fundamental questions about sleep, such as its role in rejuvenating
cognitive capacity, cellular homeostasis, and strengthening memory. And more broadly, they are exploring how it is that brain can accomplish 
such important and complex tasks, such as driving, or even breathing,
without our awareness. But for now, until we are better able to understand the inner workings
of their spontaneous functioning, we need to give our brains credit
for being much smarter than we ourselves are.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Neural circuits that produce rhythmic, repetitive patterns of spontaenous activity important for walking and breathing are called _____.
Options: A. Central pattern generators, B. Small world networks, C. The default network, D. Reflex circuits
Correct Option: A

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When we fall asleep the brain gradually transitions into slow, synchronized patterns of activity. This "slow wave sleep" is interrupted by more random, de-synchronized bursts of activity during what sleep stage?
Options: A. Stage 2, B. Stage 3, C. Stage 4, D. REM sleep
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1796, the scientist Edward Jenner injected material from a cowpox virus
into an eight-year-old boy with a hunch that this would provide
the protection needed to save people from deadly outbreaks
of the related smallpox virus. It was a success. The eight-year-old was inoculated
against the disease and this became the first ever vaccine. But why did it work? To understand how vaccines function, we need to know how the immune system
defends us against contagious diseases in the first place. When foreign microbes invade us, the immune system triggers
a series of responses in an attempt to identify
and remove them from our bodies. The signs that this immune
response is working are the coughing, sneezing,
inflammation and fever we experience, which work to trap, deter and rid the body
of threatening things, like bacteria. These innate immune responses
also trigger our second line of defense, called adaptive immunity. Special cells called B cells and T cells
are recruited to fight microbes, and also record information about them, creating a memory of what
the invaders look like, and how best to fight them. This know-how becomes handy if the same pathogen
invades the body again. But despite this smart response,
there's still a risk involved. The body takes time to learn
how to respond to pathogens and to build up these defenses. And even then, if a body is too weak or young
to fight back when it's invaded, it might face very serious risk
if the pathogen is particularly severe. But what if we could prepare
the body's immune response, readying it before someone even got ill? This is where vaccines come in. Using the same principles
that the body uses to defend itself, scientists use vaccines to trigger
the body's adaptive immune system, without exposing humans
to the full strength disease. This has resulted in many vaccines,
which each work uniquely, separated into many different types. First, we have live attenuated vaccines. These are made of the pathogen itself
but a much weaker and tamer version. Next, we have inactive vaccines,
in which the pathogens have been killed. The weakening and inactivation
in both types of vaccine ensures that pathogens don't develop
into the full blown disease. But just like a disease,
they trigger an immune response, teaching the body to recognize an attack by making a profile
of pathogens in preparation. The downside is that live attenuated
vaccines can be difficult to make, and because they're live
and quite powerful, people with weaker immune systems
can't have them, while inactive vaccines
don't create long-lasting immunity. Another type, the subunit vaccine, is only made from one part
of the pathogen, called an antigen, the ingredient that actually triggers
the immune response. By even further isolating
specific components of antigens, like proteins or polysaccharides, these vaccines can prompt
specific responses. Scientists are now building
a whole new range of vaccines called DNA vaccines. For this variety, they isolate the very
genes that make the specific antigens the body needs to trigger its immune
response to specific pathogens. When injected into the human body, those genes instruct cells
in the body to make the antigens. This causes a stronger immune response, and prepares the body
for any future threats, and because the vaccine only includes
specific genetic material, it doesn't contain any other ingredients
from the rest of the pathogen that could develop into the disease
and harm the patient. If these vaccines become a success, we might be able to build
more effective treatments for invasive pathogens in years to come. Just like Edward Jenner's
amazing discovery spurred on modern medicine
all those decades ago, continuing the development of vaccines might even allow us
to treat diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola, one day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Edward Jenner succeeded in creating a vaccine against smallpox by injecting patients with material of which disease?
Options: A. Smallpox, B. Cowpox, C. Cattle virus, D. Measles virus
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with creating the first vaccine by injecting material from a cowpox virus into an eight-year-old boy? Options: A. Louis Pasteur, B. Edward Jenner, C. Robert Koch, D. Jonas Salk Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of the immune system when foreign microbes invade the body? Options: A. To produce antibodies immediately, B. To trigger a series of responses to identify and remove the microbes, C. To create a memory of the invading pathogens, D. To fight the microbes using only B cells Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of immunity is triggered by the innate immune responses and involves the recruitment of B cells and T cells? Options: A. Innate immunity, B. Adaptive immunity, C. Passive immunity, D. Active immunity Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main advantage of vaccines in preparing the body's immune response? Options: A. Vaccines cure diseases immediately, B. Vaccines provide temporary immunity, C. Vaccines trigger the body's adaptive immune system without exposing humans to the full-strength disease, D. Vaccines only work for bacterial infections Correct Option: None
Question 5: What type of vaccine is made from a weakened and tamer version of the pathogen itself? Options: A. Inactive vaccine, B. Live attenuated vaccine, C. Subunit vaccine, D. DNA vaccine Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the main disadvantage of live attenuated vaccines? Options: A. They are difficult to make and may not be suitable for people with weaker immune systems, B. They do not provide long-lasting immunity, C. They are only effective against bacterial infections, D. They are too expensive to produce Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of vaccine is made from only one part of the pathogen, called an antigen? Options: A. Live attenuated vaccine, B. Inactive vaccine, C. Subunit vaccine, D. DNA vaccine Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do DNA vaccines work? Options: A. By injecting the pathogen itself into the body, B. By isolating the genes that make specific antigens and instructing cells to make those antigens, C. By providing temporary immunity, D. By curing diseases immediately Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is a potential benefit of DNA vaccines? Options: A. They may not provide long-lasting immunity, B. They may be too expensive to produce, C. They may allow for the treatment of diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola, D. They may only work for bacterial infections Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the result of Edward Jenner's experiment with the cowpox virus? Options: A. The eight-year-old boy developed smallpox, B. The eight-year-old boy was inoculated against smallpox, C. The eight-year-old boy showed no immune response, D. The eight-year-old boy developed a severe reaction to the vaccine Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10: What was the result of Edward Jenner's experiment with the cowpox virus? Options: A. The eight-year-old boy developed smallpox, B. The eight-year-old boy was inoculated against smallpox, C. The eight-year-old boy showed no immune response, D. The eight-year-old boy developed a severe reaction to the vaccine.

However, this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the result of the experiment, not the material used to create the vaccine. 

A more similar question would be one that asks about the material used to create the vaccine, but such a question is not present in the generated MCQs. The closest match would be Question 1, but it asks about who created the vaccine, not the material used.

If we had to choose from the given options, the closest match would be Question 1, as it mentions Edward Jenner and cowpox virus, but it does not match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
In 1796, the scientist Edward Jenner injected material from a cowpox virus
into an eight-year-old boy with a hunch that this would provide
the protection needed to save people from deadly outbreaks
of the related smallpox virus. It was a success. The eight-year-old was inoculated

a series of responses in an attempt to identify
and remove them from our bodies. The signs that this immune

inflammation and fever we experience, which work to trap, deter and rid the body
of threatening things, like bacteria. These innate immune responses
also trigger our second line of defense, called adaptive immunity. Special cells called B cells and T cells

the invaders look like, and how best to fight them. This know-how becomes handy if the same pathogen

there's still a risk involved. The body takes time to learn

they trigger an immune response, teaching the body to recognize an attack by making a profile
of pathogens in preparation. The downside is that live attenuated

and quite powerful, people with weaker immune systems
can't have them, while inactive vaccines
don't create long-lasting immunity. Another type, the subunit vaccine, is only made from one part

more effective treatments for invasive pathogens in years to come. Just like Edward Jenner's
amazing discovery spurred on modern medicine
all those decades ago, continuing the development of vaccines might even allow us
to treat diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola, one day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the function of innate immune response?
Options: A. Act very rapid as a first line of defense to eliminate the infection, B. Trap microbes so they cannot spread in our body freely, C. Coordinate and support adaptive immunity, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Question 7: What type of vaccine is made from only one part of the pathogen, called an antigen? Options: A. Live attenuated vaccine, B. Inactive vaccine, C. Subunit vaccine, D. DNA vaccine Correct Option: None

Question 9: What is a potential benefit of DNA vaccines? Options: A. They may not provide long-lasting immunity, B. They may be too expensive to produce, C. They may allow for the treatment of diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola, D. They may only work for bacterial infections Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the result of Edward Jenner's experiment with the cowpox virus? Options: A. The eight-year-old boy developed smallpox, B. The eight-year-old boy was inoculated against smallpox, C. The eight-year-old boy showed no immune response, D. The eight-year-old boy developed a severe reaction to the vaccine Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is Question 2. Although it does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest in terms of question intent, options, and content.

Question 2 asks about the primary function of the immune system when foreign microbes invade the body, which is related to the innate immune response. The correct answer, "To trigger a series of responses to identify and remove the microbes," is similar to option D in the ground truth MCQ, "All of the above," which includes "Act very rapid as a first line of defense to eliminate the infection" and "Trap microbes so they cannot spread in our body freely."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1796, the scientist Edward Jenner injected material from a cowpox virus
into an eight-year-old boy with a hunch that this would provide
the protection needed to save people from deadly outbreaks
of the related smallpox virus. It was a success. The eight-year-old was inoculated
against the disease and this became the first ever vaccine. But why did it work? To understand how vaccines function, we need to know how the immune system
defends us against contagious diseases in the first place. When foreign microbes invade us, the immune system triggers
a series of responses in an attempt to identify
and remove them from our bodies. The signs that this immune
response is working are the coughing, sneezing,
inflammation and fever we experience, which work to trap, deter and rid the body
of threatening things, like bacteria. These innate immune responses
also trigger our second line of defense, called adaptive immunity. Special cells called B cells and T cells
are recruited to fight microbes, and also record information about them, creating a memory of what
the invaders look like, and how best to fight them. This know-how becomes handy if the same pathogen
invades the body again. But despite this smart response,
there's still a risk involved. The body takes time to learn
how to respond to pathogens and to build up these defenses. And even then, if a body is too weak or young
to fight back when it's invaded, it might face very serious risk
if the pathogen is particularly severe. But what if we could prepare
the body's immune response, readying it before someone even got ill? This is where vaccines come in. Using the same principles
that the body uses to defend itself, scientists use vaccines to trigger
the body's adaptive immune system, without exposing humans
to the full strength disease. This has resulted in many vaccines,
which each work uniquely, separated into many different types. First, we have live attenuated vaccines. These are made of the pathogen itself
but a much weaker and tamer version. Next, we have inactive vaccines,
in which the pathogens have been killed. The weakening and inactivation
in both types of vaccine ensures that pathogens don't develop
into the full blown disease. But just like a disease,
they trigger an immune response, teaching the body to recognize an attack by making a profile
of pathogens in preparation. The downside is that live attenuated
vaccines can be difficult to make, and because they're live
and quite powerful, people with weaker immune systems
can't have them, while inactive vaccines
don't create long-lasting immunity. Another type, the subunit vaccine, is only made from one part
of the pathogen, called an antigen, the ingredient that actually triggers
the immune response. By even further isolating
specific components of antigens, like proteins or polysaccharides, these vaccines can prompt
specific responses. Scientists are now building
a whole new range of vaccines called DNA vaccines. For this variety, they isolate the very
genes that make the specific antigens the body needs to trigger its immune
response to specific pathogens. When injected into the human body, those genes instruct cells
in the body to make the antigens. This causes a stronger immune response, and prepares the body
for any future threats, and because the vaccine only includes
specific genetic material, it doesn't contain any other ingredients
from the rest of the pathogen that could develop into the disease
and harm the patient. If these vaccines become a success, we might be able to build
more effective treatments for invasive pathogens in years to come. Just like Edward Jenner's
amazing discovery spurred on modern medicine
all those decades ago, continuing the development of vaccines might even allow us
to treat diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola, one day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the main advantage of live attenuated vaccine?
Options: A. It provides more durable immunity; boosters may be required, though less frequently than would otherwise be necessary, B. It is safer than other kinds of vaccines, C. It does not cause any severe side effects or complications, D. It is suitable for people with any type of health
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with creating the first vaccine by injecting material from a cowpox virus into an eight-year-old boy? Options: A. Louis Pasteur, B. Edward Jenner, C. Robert Koch, D. Jonas Salk Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of the immune system when foreign microbes invade the body? Options: A. To produce antibodies immediately, B. To trigger a series of responses to identify and remove the microbes, C. To create a memory of the invading pathogens, D. To fight the microbes using only B cells Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of immunity is triggered by the innate immune responses and involves the recruitment of B cells and T cells? Options: A. Innate immunity, B. Adaptive immunity, C. Passive immunity, D. Active immunity Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the main advantage of vaccines in preparing the body's immune response? Options: A. Vaccines cure diseases immediately, B. Vaccines provide temporary immunity, C. Vaccines trigger the body's adaptive immune system without exposing humans to the full-strength disease, D. Vaccines only work for bacterial infections Correct Option: None
Question 5: What type of vaccine is made from a weakened and tamer version of the pathogen itself? Options: A. Inactive vaccine, B. Live attenuated vaccine, C. Subunit vaccine, D. DNA vaccine Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the main disadvantage of live attenuated vaccines? Options: A. They are difficult to make and may not be suitable for people with weaker immune systems, B. They do not provide long-lasting immunity, C. They are only effective against bacterial infections, D. They are too expensive to produce Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of vaccine is made from only one part of the pathogen, called an antigen? Options: A. Live attenuated vaccine, B. Inactive vaccine, C. Subunit vaccine, D. DNA vaccine Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do DNA vaccines work? Options: A. By injecting the pathogen itself into the body, B. By isolating the genes that make specific antigens and instructing cells to make those antigens, C. By providing temporary immunity, D. By curing diseases immediately Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is a potential benefit of DNA vaccines? Options: A. They may not provide long-lasting immunity, B. They may be too expensive to produce, C. They may allow for the treatment of diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola, D. They may only work for bacterial infections Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the result of Edward Jenner's experiment with the cowpox virus? Options: A. The eight-year-old boy developed smallpox, B. The eight-year-old boy was inoculated against smallpox, C. The eight-year-old boy showed no immune response, D. The eight-year-old boy developed a severe reaction to the vaccine Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. 

Although Question 6 is asking about the main disadvantage of live attenuated vaccines, one of its options (A) mentions a characteristic of live attenuated vaccines that is related to the main advantage mentioned in the ground truth MCQ (i.e., they are difficult to make and may not be suitable for people with weaker immune systems, implying that when they can be used, they provide more durable immunity). However, none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that directly asks about the main advantage of live attenuated vaccines and has options that include the correct answer, such as providing more durable immunity. Unfortunately, such a generated MCQ does not exist in the provided set.

Therefore, while not a perfect match, Question 6 is the closest match based on the content and options provided.

In 1796, the scientist Edward Jenner injected material from a cowpox virus
into an eight-year-old boy with a hunch that this would provide
the protection needed to save people from deadly outbreaks
of the related smallpox virus. It was a success. The eight-year-old was inoculated

defends us against contagious diseases in the first place. When foreign microbes invade us, the immune system triggers
a series of responses in an attempt to identify
and remove them from our bodies. The signs that this immune
response is working are the coughing, sneezing,
inflammation and fever we experience, which work to trap, deter and rid the body
of threatening things, like bacteria. These innate immune responses
also trigger our second line of defense, called adaptive immunity. Special cells called B cells and T cells
are recruited to fight microbes, and also record information about them, creating a memory of what
the invaders look like, and how best to fight them. This know-how becomes handy if the same pathogen
invades the body again. But despite this smart response,
there's still a risk involved. The body takes time to learn
how to respond to pathogens and to build up these defenses. And even then, if a body is too weak or young
to fight back when it's invaded, it might face very serious risk
if the pathogen is particularly severe. But what if we could prepare
the body's immune response, readying it before someone even got ill? This is where vaccines come in. Using the same principles
that the body uses to defend itself, scientists use vaccines to trigger
the body's adaptive immune system, without exposing humans
to the full strength disease. This has resulted in many vaccines,
which each work uniquely, separated into many different types. First, we have live attenuated vaccines. These are made of the pathogen itself
but a much weaker and tamer version. Next, we have inactive vaccines,
in which the pathogens have been killed. The weakening and inactivation
in both types of vaccine ensures that pathogens don't develop
into the full blown disease. But just like a disease,
they trigger an immune response, teaching the body to recognize an attack by making a profile
of pathogens in preparation. The downside is that live attenuated
vaccines can be difficult to make, and because they're live
and quite powerful, people with weaker immune systems
can't have them, while inactive vaccines
don't create long-lasting immunity. Another type, the subunit vaccine, is only made from one part
of the pathogen, called an antigen, the ingredient that actually triggers
the immune response. By even further isolating
specific components of antigens, like proteins or polysaccharides, these vaccines can prompt
specific responses. Scientists are now building
a whole new range of vaccines called DNA vaccines. For this variety, they isolate the very
genes that make the specific antigens the body needs to trigger its immune
response to specific pathogens. When injected into the human body, those genes instruct cells
in the body to make the antigens. This causes a stronger immune response, and prepares the body
for any future threats, and because the vaccine only includes
specific genetic material, it doesn't contain any other ingredients
from the rest of the pathogen that could develop into the disease
and harm the patient. If these vaccines become a success, we might be able to build
more effective treatments for invasive pathogens in years to come. Just like Edward Jenner's
amazing discovery spurred on modern medicine
all those decades ago, continuing the development of vaccines might even allow us
to treat diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola, one day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which is not true about subunit vaccines?
Options: A. They can be designed using molecular biology technique, B. They are less harmful than live attenuated vaccine, C. They generally are made of polypeptide or oligopeptide, D. They provide lifetime protection
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1796, the scientist Edward Jenner injected material from a cowpox virus
into an eight-year-old boy with a hunch that this would provide
the protection needed to save people from deadly outbreaks
of the related smallpox virus. It was a success. The eight-year-old was inoculated
against the disease and this became the first ever vaccine. But why did it work? To understand how vaccines function, we need to know how the immune system
defends us against contagious diseases in the first place. When foreign microbes invade us, the immune system triggers
a series of responses in an attempt to identify
and remove them from our bodies. The signs that this immune
response is working are the coughing, sneezing,
inflammation and fever we experience, which work to trap, deter and rid the body
of threatening things, like bacteria. These innate immune responses
also trigger our second line of defense, called adaptive immunity. Special cells called B cells and T cells
are recruited to fight microbes, and also record information about them, creating a memory of what
the invaders look like, and how best to fight them. This know-how becomes handy if the same pathogen
invades the body again. But despite this smart response,
there's still a risk involved. The body takes time to learn
how to respond to pathogens and to build up these defenses. And even then, if a body is too weak or young
to fight back when it's invaded, it might face very serious risk
if the pathogen is particularly severe. But what if we could prepare
the body's immune response, readying it before someone even got ill? This is where vaccines come in. Using the same principles
that the body uses to defend itself, scientists use vaccines to trigger
the body's adaptive immune system, without exposing humans
to the full strength disease. This has resulted in many vaccines,
which each work uniquely, separated into many different types. First, we have live attenuated vaccines. These are made of the pathogen itself
but a much weaker and tamer version. Next, we have inactive vaccines,
in which the pathogens have been killed. The weakening and inactivation
in both types of vaccine ensures that pathogens don't develop
into the full blown disease. But just like a disease,
they trigger an immune response, teaching the body to recognize an attack by making a profile
of pathogens in preparation. The downside is that live attenuated
vaccines can be difficult to make, and because they're live
and quite powerful, people with weaker immune systems
can't have them, while inactive vaccines
don't create long-lasting immunity. Another type, the subunit vaccine, is only made from one part
of the pathogen, called an antigen, the ingredient that actually triggers
the immune response. By even further isolating
specific components of antigens, like proteins or polysaccharides, these vaccines can prompt
specific responses. Scientists are now building
a whole new range of vaccines called DNA vaccines. For this variety, they isolate the very
genes that make the specific antigens the body needs to trigger its immune
response to specific pathogens. When injected into the human body, those genes instruct cells
in the body to make the antigens. This causes a stronger immune response, and prepares the body
for any future threats, and because the vaccine only includes
specific genetic material, it doesn't contain any other ingredients
from the rest of the pathogen that could develop into the disease
and harm the patient. If these vaccines become a success, we might be able to build
more effective treatments for invasive pathogens in years to come. Just like Edward Jenner's
amazing discovery spurred on modern medicine
all those decades ago, continuing the development of vaccines might even allow us
to treat diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola, one day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Since we have our immune system to protect us from disease, why do we still need a vaccine?
Options: A. Because some diseases are too severe for our immune system, B. Because adaptive immunity takes days to weeks to initiate a response and sometimes it is too late, C. Because some people are immune deficient or have weak immune systems, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D
