**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed something swimming
in your field of vision? It may look like a tiny worm
or a transparent blob, and whenever you try to get
a closer look, it disappears, only to reappear
as soon as you shift your glance. But don't go rinsing out your eyes! What you are seeing is a common phenomenon known as a floater. The scientific name for these objects
is Muscae volitantes, Latin for "flying flies," and true to their name,
they can be somewhat annoying. But they're not actually bugs
or any kind of external objects at all. Rather, they exist inside your eyeball. Floaters may seem to be alive,
since they move and change shape, but they are not alive. Floaters are tiny objects
that cast shadows on the retina, the light-sensitive tissue
at the back of your eye. They might be bits of tissue, red blood cells, or clumps of protein. And because they're suspended
within the vitreous humor, the gel-like liquid
that fills the inside of your eye, floaters drift along
with your eye movements, and seem to bounce a little
when your eye stops. Floaters may be only
barely distinguishable most of the time. They become more visible
the closer they are to the retina, just as holding your hand closer
to a table with an overhead light will result in a more
sharply defined shadow. And floaters are particularly noticeable when you are looking
at a uniform bright surface, like a blank computer screen, snow, or a clear sky, where the consistency of the background
makes them easier to distinguish. The brighter the light is,
the more your pupil contracts. This has an effect similar
to replacing a large diffuse light fixture with a single overhead light bulb, which also makes
the shadow appear clearer. There is another visual phenomenon
that looks similar to floaters but is in fact unrelated. If you've seen tiny dots of light
darting about when looking at a bright blue sky, you've experienced what is known
as the blue field entoptic phenomenon. In some ways,
this is the opposite of seeing floaters. Here, you are not seeing shadows but little moving windows
letting light through to your retina. The windows are actually caused
by white blood cells moving through the capillaries
along your retina's surface. These leukocytes can be so large
that they nearly fill a capillary causing a plasma space
to open up in front of them. Because the space
and the white blood cells are both more transparent to blue light than the red blood cells
normally present in capillaries, we see a moving dot of light
wherever this happens, following the paths of your capillaries
and moving in time with your pulse. Under ideal viewing conditions, you might even see what looks
like a dark tail following the dot. This is the red blood cells
that have bunched up behind the leukocyte. Some science museums have an exhibit
which consists of a screen of blue light, allowing you to see these blue sky sprites
much more clearly than you normally would. While everybody's eyes experience
these sort of effects, the number and type vary greatly. In the case of floaters, they often go unnoticed,
as our brain learns to ignore them. However, abnormally numerous or large floaters
that interfere with vision may be a sign of a more serious condition,
requiring immediate medical treatment. But the majority of the time
entoptic phenomena, such as floaters and blue sky sprites, are just a gentle reminder
that what we think we see depends just as much
on our biology and minds as it does on the external world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why can you see floaters more easily when your pupil contracts?
Options: A. Because less light enters your eye, B. Because the light enters your eye through a smaller area, C. Because floaters move when the pupil moves, D. Because the shadows are bigger, E. All of the above, F. None of the above
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the scientific name for the phenomenon known as "floaters" in the human eye? Options: A. Muscae externae, B. Muscae volitantes, C. Vitreous humor, D. Retina sensitiva Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the cause of the appearance of floaters in the human eye? Options: A. External objects entering the eye, B. Bits of tissue, red blood cells, or clumps of protein casting shadows on the retina, C. Abnormalities in the cornea, D. Infections in the eye Correct Option: None
Question 3: Where are floaters suspended within the eye? Options: A. In the aqueous humor, B. In the vitreous humor, C. In the retina, D. In the cornea Correct Option: None
Question 4: When do floaters become more visible? Options: A. In low light conditions, B. When looking at a uniform bright surface, C. When the eye is at rest, D. When the eye is moving rapidly Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the effect of a contracting pupil on the visibility of floaters? Options: A. It makes them less visible, B. It makes them more visible, C. It has no effect on their visibility, D. It changes their color Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the blue field entoptic phenomenon? Options: A. A type of floater, B. A type of eye infection, C. A visual phenomenon caused by white blood cells moving through capillaries along the retina's surface, D. A type of eye disease Correct Option: None
Question 7: What causes the appearance of moving dots of light in the blue field entoptic phenomenon? Options: A. Shadows cast by floaters, B. White blood cells moving through capillaries along the retina's surface, C. Red blood cells moving through capillaries along the retina's surface, D. The movement of the eye Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why do the moving dots of light in the blue field entoptic phenomenon appear blue? Options: A. Because the white blood cells are blue in color, B. Because the capillaries along the retina's surface are blue in color, C. Because the space and the white blood cells are more transparent to blue light than the red blood cells, D. Because the eye is more sensitive to blue light Correct Option: None
Question 9: What can be a sign of a more serious condition requiring immediate medical treatment? Options: A. The presence of floaters, B. The presence of the blue field entoptic phenomenon, C. Abnormally numerous or large floaters that interfere with vision, D. The absence of floaters Correct Option: None
Question 10: What do entoptic phenomena, such as floaters and blue sky sprites, remind us of? Options: A. The importance of regular eye exams, B. The complexity of the human eye, C. That what we think we see depends just as much on our biology and minds as it does on the external world, D. The fragility of the human eye Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What is the effect of a contracting pupil on the visibility of floaters? 

Although the options do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, the intent and content of the question are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks why floaters are more easily seen when the pupil contracts, and the correct answer is that the light enters the eye through a smaller area. Question 5 asks about the effect of a contracting pupil on the visibility of floaters, which is a similar concept.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Have you ever noticed something swimming
in your field of vision? It may look like a tiny worm
or a transparent blob, and whenever you try to get
a closer look, it disappears, only to reappear
as soon as you shift your glance. But don't go rinsing out your eyes! What you are seeing is a common phenomenon known as a floater. The scientific name for these objects
is Muscae volitantes, Latin for "flying flies," and true to their name,
they can be somewhat annoying. But they're not actually bugs
or any kind of external objects at all. Rather, they exist inside your eyeball. Floaters may seem to be alive,
since they move and change shape, but they are not alive. Floaters are tiny objects
that cast shadows on the retina, the light-sensitive tissue
at the back of your eye. They might be bits of tissue, red blood cells, or clumps of protein. And because they're suspended
within the vitreous humor, the gel-like liquid
that fills the inside of your eye, floaters drift along
with your eye movements, and seem to bounce a little
when your eye stops. Floaters may be only
barely distinguishable most of the time. They become more visible
the closer they are to the retina, just as holding your hand closer
to a table with an overhead light will result in a more
sharply defined shadow. And floaters are particularly noticeable when you are looking
at a uniform bright surface, like a blank computer screen, snow, or a clear sky, where the consistency of the background
makes them easier to distinguish. The brighter the light is,
the more your pupil contracts. This has an effect similar
to replacing a large diffuse light fixture with a single overhead light bulb, which also makes
the shadow appear clearer. There is another visual phenomenon
that looks similar to floaters but is in fact unrelated. If you've seen tiny dots of light
darting about when looking at a bright blue sky, you've experienced what is known
as the blue field entoptic phenomenon. In some ways,
this is the opposite of seeing floaters. Here, you are not seeing shadows but little moving windows
letting light through to your retina. The windows are actually caused
by white blood cells moving through the capillaries
along your retina's surface. These leukocytes can be so large
that they nearly fill a capillary causing a plasma space
to open up in front of them. Because the space
and the white blood cells are both more transparent to blue light than the red blood cells
normally present in capillaries, we see a moving dot of light
wherever this happens, following the paths of your capillaries
and moving in time with your pulse. Under ideal viewing conditions, you might even see what looks
like a dark tail following the dot. This is the red blood cells
that have bunched up behind the leukocyte. Some science museums have an exhibit
which consists of a screen of blue light, allowing you to see these blue sky sprites
much more clearly than you normally would. While everybody's eyes experience
these sort of effects, the number and type vary greatly. In the case of floaters, they often go unnoticed,
as our brain learns to ignore them. However, abnormally numerous or large floaters
that interfere with vision may be a sign of a more serious condition,
requiring immediate medical treatment. But the majority of the time
entoptic phenomena, such as floaters and blue sky sprites, are just a gentle reminder
that what we think we see depends just as much
on our biology and minds as it does on the external world.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Floaters are more visible:
Options: A. In bright light, B. When looking at a uniform surface, C. When they are closer to the retina, D. All of the above, E. None of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a factory inside you 
that weighs about 1.4 kilograms and runs for 24 hours a day. This is your liver,
the heaviest organ in your body, and one of the most crucial. This industrious structure 
simultaneously acts as a storehouse, a manufacturing hub, and a processing plant. And each of these functions involve 
so many important subtasks that without the liver, 
our bodies would simply stop working. One of the liver's main functions 
is to filter the body's blood, which it receives in regular shipments 
from two sources: the hepatic artery 
delivers blood from the heart, while the hepatic portal vein 
brings it from the intestine. This double delivery 
fills the liver with nutrients, that it then sorts, processes and stores with the help of thousands 
of tiny internal processing plants, known as lobules. Both blood flows also deliver the oxygen 
that the liver needs to function. The blood that is received 
from the intestine contains carbohydrates, fats, and vitamins and other nutrients 
dissolved in it from the food you've consumed. These must be processed in different ways. In the case of carbohydrates, the liver breaks them down 
and converts them into sugars for the body to use as energy 
when the filtered blood is sent back out. Sometimes the body 
has leftovers of nutrients that it doesn't immediately require. When that happens, 
the liver holds some back, and stacks them in its storage facility. This facility works like a pantry for future cases when the body 
might be in need of nutrients. But the blood flowing into the liver
isn't always full of good things. It also contains toxins
and byproducts that the body can't use. And the liver monitors these strictly. When it spots
a useless or toxic substance, it either converts it into a product 
that can't hurt the body or isolates it and whisks it away, channeling it through 
the kidneys and intestine to be excreted. Of course, we wouldn't consider 
the liver a factory if it didn't also manufacture things. This organ makes everything 
from various blood plasma proteins that transport fatty acids 
and help form blood clots, to the cholesterol 
that helps the body create hormones. It also makes vitamin D
and substances that help digestion. But one of its most vital products 
is bile. Like an eco-friendly treatment plant, the liver uses cells called hepatocytes to convert toxic waste products 
into this bitter greenish liquid. As it's produced, bile is funneled 
into a small container below the liver, called the gallbladder, before being trickled into the intestine to help break down fats, destroy microbes,
and neutralize extra stomach acid. Bile also helps carry other toxins 
and byproducts from the liver out of the body. So as you can see, the liver is an extremely efficient 
industrial site, performing multiple tasks 
that support each other. But such a complex system 
needs to be kept running smoothly by keeping it healthy and not overloading it 
with more toxins than it can handle. This is one factory 
we simply can't afford to shut down.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The liver receives blood from:
Options: A. The lobules, B. The stomach and the gall bladder, C. Veins and arteries, D. The hepatic artery and the hepatic portal vein
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate weight of the liver in the human body? Options: A. 0.5 kilograms, B. 1.4 kilograms, C. 2.5 kilograms, D. 3.5 kilograms Correct Option: None
Question 2: What are the two main sources of blood that the liver receives? Options: A. Hepatic artery and pulmonary vein, B. Hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein, C. Pulmonary artery and hepatic portal vein, D. Pulmonary artery and hepatic artery Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the main function of the tiny internal processing plants in the liver, known as lobules? Options: A. To produce bile, B. To filter the body's blood, C. To sort, process, and store nutrients, D. To produce cholesterol Correct Option: None
Question 4: What does the liver convert carbohydrates into for the body to use as energy? Options: A. Fats, B. Proteins, C. Sugars, D. Vitamins Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens to the leftover nutrients that the body doesn't immediately require? Options: A. They are excreted through the kidneys, B. They are stored in the liver's storage facility, C. They are converted into toxins, D. They are sent back to the intestine Correct Option: None
Question 6: What does the liver do with toxic substances that it detects in the blood? Options: A. It converts them into useful nutrients, B. It isolates them and whisks them away for excretion, C. It stores them in its storage facility, D. It ignores them Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is one of the vital products manufactured by the liver? Options: A. Insulin, B. Bile, C. Adrenaline, D. Thyroid hormone Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the function of bile in the digestive system? Options: A. To break down carbohydrates, B. To break down proteins, C. To break down fats, destroy microbes, and neutralize extra stomach acid, D. To produce vitamins Correct Option: None
Question 9: Where is bile stored before it is released into the intestine? Options: A. Liver, B. Gallbladder, C. Pancreas, D. Stomach Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it essential to keep the liver healthy? Options: A. So it can produce more bile, B. So it can store more nutrients, C. So it can perform its multiple tasks efficiently and support overall bodily functions, D. So it can filter more blood Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the two main sources of blood that the liver receives. The options in Question 2 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct answer being the hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 2

There's a factory inside you 
that weighs about 1.4 kilograms and runs for 24 hours a day. This is your liver,
the heaviest organ in your body, and one of the most crucial. This industrious structure 
simultaneously acts as a storehouse, a manufacturing hub, and a processing plant. And each of these functions involve 
so many important subtasks that without the liver, 
our bodies would simply stop working. One of the liver's main functions 
is to filter the body's blood, which it receives in regular shipments 
from two sources: the hepatic artery 
delivers blood from the heart, while the hepatic portal vein

fills the liver with nutrients, that it then sorts, processes and stores with the help of thousands 
of tiny internal processing plants, known as lobules. Both blood flows also deliver the oxygen 
that the liver needs to function. The blood that is received 
from the intestine contains carbohydrates, fats, and vitamins and other nutrients 
dissolved in it from the food you've consumed. These must be processed in different ways. In the case of carbohydrates, the liver breaks them down

that support each other. But such a complex system 
needs to be kept running smoothly by keeping it healthy and not overloading it 
with more toxins than it can handle. This is one factory 
we simply can't afford to shut down.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a factory inside you 
that weighs about 1.4 kilograms and runs for 24 hours a day. This is your liver,
the heaviest organ in your body, and one of the most crucial. This industrious structure 
simultaneously acts as a storehouse, a manufacturing hub, and a processing plant. And each of these functions involve 
so many important subtasks that without the liver, 
our bodies would simply stop working. One of the liver's main functions 
is to filter the body's blood, which it receives in regular shipments 
from two sources: the hepatic artery 
delivers blood from the heart, while the hepatic portal vein 
brings it from the intestine. This double delivery 
fills the liver with nutrients, that it then sorts, processes and stores with the help of thousands 
of tiny internal processing plants, known as lobules. Both blood flows also deliver the oxygen 
that the liver needs to function. The blood that is received 
from the intestine contains carbohydrates, fats, and vitamins and other nutrients 
dissolved in it from the food you've consumed. These must be processed in different ways. In the case of carbohydrates, the liver breaks them down 
and converts them into sugars for the body to use as energy 
when the filtered blood is sent back out. Sometimes the body 
has leftovers of nutrients that it doesn't immediately require. When that happens, 
the liver holds some back, and stacks them in its storage facility. This facility works like a pantry for future cases when the body 
might be in need of nutrients. But the blood flowing into the liver
isn't always full of good things. It also contains toxins
and byproducts that the body can't use. And the liver monitors these strictly. When it spots
a useless or toxic substance, it either converts it into a product 
that can't hurt the body or isolates it and whisks it away, channeling it through 
the kidneys and intestine to be excreted. Of course, we wouldn't consider 
the liver a factory if it didn't also manufacture things. This organ makes everything 
from various blood plasma proteins that transport fatty acids 
and help form blood clots, to the cholesterol 
that helps the body create hormones. It also makes vitamin D
and substances that help digestion. But one of its most vital products 
is bile. Like an eco-friendly treatment plant, the liver uses cells called hepatocytes to convert toxic waste products 
into this bitter greenish liquid. As it's produced, bile is funneled 
into a small container below the liver, called the gallbladder, before being trickled into the intestine to help break down fats, destroy microbes,
and neutralize extra stomach acid. Bile also helps carry other toxins 
and byproducts from the liver out of the body. So as you can see, the liver is an extremely efficient 
industrial site, performing multiple tasks 
that support each other. But such a complex system 
needs to be kept running smoothly by keeping it healthy and not overloading it 
with more toxins than it can handle. This is one factory 
we simply can't afford to shut down.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Inside the liver, the ______ help the organ to process and store nutrients
Options: A. Lobules, B. Hepatic cells, C. Liver cells, D. Bile fluids
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 3: What is the main function of the tiny internal processing plants in the liver, known as lobules? Options: A. To produce bile, B. To filter the body's blood, C. To sort, process, and store nutrients, D. To produce cholesterol Correct Option: None
Question 4: What does the liver convert carbohydrates into for the body to use as energy? Options: A. Fats, B. Proteins, C. Sugars, D. Vitamins Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens to the leftover nutrients that the body doesn't immediately require? Options: A. They are excreted through the kidneys, B. They are stored in the liver's storage facility, C. They are converted into toxins, D. They are sent back to the intestine Correct Option: None
Question 6: What does the liver do with toxic substances that it detects in the blood? Options: A. It converts them into useful nutrients, B. It isolates them and whisks them away for excretion, C. It stores them in its storage facility, D. It ignores them Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is one of the vital products manufactured by the liver? Options: A. Insulin, B. Bile, C. Adrenaline, D. Thyroid hormone Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the function of bile in the digestive system? Options: A. To break down carbohydrates, B. To break down proteins, C. To break down fats, destroy microbes, and neutralize extra stomach acid, D. To produce vitamins Correct Option: None
Question 9: Where is bile stored before it is released into the intestine? Options: A. Liver, B. Gallbladder, C. Pancreas, D. Stomach Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it essential to keep the liver healthy? Options: A. So it can produce more bile, B. So it can store more nutrients, C. So it can perform its multiple tasks efficiently and support overall bodily functions, D. So it can filter more blood Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question asks about the main function of the tiny internal processing plants in the liver, known as lobules, which aligns with the ground truth MCQ's focus on the role of lobules in processing and storing nutrients. The correct option in Question 3 (C. To sort, process, and store nutrients) also matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (A. Lobules).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a factory inside you 
that weighs about 1.4 kilograms and runs for 24 hours a day. This is your liver,
the heaviest organ in your body, and one of the most crucial. This industrious structure 
simultaneously acts as a storehouse, a manufacturing hub, and a processing plant. And each of these functions involve 
so many important subtasks that without the liver, 
our bodies would simply stop working. One of the liver's main functions 
is to filter the body's blood, which it receives in regular shipments 
from two sources: the hepatic artery 
delivers blood from the heart, while the hepatic portal vein 
brings it from the intestine. This double delivery 
fills the liver with nutrients, that it then sorts, processes and stores with the help of thousands 
of tiny internal processing plants, known as lobules. Both blood flows also deliver the oxygen 
that the liver needs to function. The blood that is received 
from the intestine contains carbohydrates, fats, and vitamins and other nutrients 
dissolved in it from the food you've consumed. These must be processed in different ways. In the case of carbohydrates, the liver breaks them down 
and converts them into sugars for the body to use as energy 
when the filtered blood is sent back out. Sometimes the body 
has leftovers of nutrients that it doesn't immediately require. When that happens, 
the liver holds some back, and stacks them in its storage facility. This facility works like a pantry for future cases when the body 
might be in need of nutrients. But the blood flowing into the liver
isn't always full of good things. It also contains toxins
and byproducts that the body can't use. And the liver monitors these strictly. When it spots
a useless or toxic substance, it either converts it into a product 
that can't hurt the body or isolates it and whisks it away, channeling it through 
the kidneys and intestine to be excreted. Of course, we wouldn't consider 
the liver a factory if it didn't also manufacture things. This organ makes everything 
from various blood plasma proteins that transport fatty acids 
and help form blood clots, to the cholesterol 
that helps the body create hormones. It also makes vitamin D
and substances that help digestion. But one of its most vital products 
is bile. Like an eco-friendly treatment plant, the liver uses cells called hepatocytes to convert toxic waste products 
into this bitter greenish liquid. As it's produced, bile is funneled 
into a small container below the liver, called the gallbladder, before being trickled into the intestine to help break down fats, destroy microbes,
and neutralize extra stomach acid. Bile also helps carry other toxins 
and byproducts from the liver out of the body. So as you can see, the liver is an extremely efficient 
industrial site, performing multiple tasks 
that support each other. But such a complex system 
needs to be kept running smoothly by keeping it healthy and not overloading it 
with more toxins than it can handle. This is one factory 
we simply can't afford to shut down.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When the liver encounters more nutrients than the body needs, it:
Options: A. Dissolves them, B. Sends them to the kidneys, C. Stores them for later, D. Converts them into something else
Correct Option: C

Question 2: What are the two main sources of blood that the liver receives? Options: A. Hepatic artery and pulmonary vein, B. Hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein, C. Pulmonary artery and hepatic portal vein, D. Pulmonary artery and hepatic artery Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the main function of the tiny internal processing plants in the liver, known as lobules? Options: A. To produce bile, B. To filter the body's blood, C. To sort, process, and store nutrients, D. To produce cholesterol Correct Option: None
Question 4: What does the liver convert carbohydrates into for the body to use as energy? Options: A. Fats, B. Proteins, C. Sugars, D. Vitamins Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens to the leftover nutrients that the body doesn't immediately require? Options: A. They are excreted through the kidneys, B. They are stored in the liver's storage facility, C. They are converted into toxins, D. They are sent back to the intestine Correct Option: None
Question 6: What does the liver do with toxic substances that it detects in the blood? Options: A. It converts them into useful nutrients, B. It isolates them and whisks them away for excretion, C. It stores them in its storage facility, D. It ignores them Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is one of the vital products manufactured by the liver? Options: A. Insulin, B. Bile, C. Adrenaline, D. Thyroid hormone Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the function of bile in the digestive system? Options: A. To break down carbohydrates, B. To break down proteins, C. To break down fats, destroy microbes, and neutralize extra stomach acid, D. To produce vitamins Correct Option: None
Question 9: Where is bile stored before it is released into the intestine? Options: A. Liver, B. Gallbladder, C. Pancreas, D. Stomach Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it essential to keep the liver healthy? Options: A. So it can produce more bile, B. So it can store more nutrients, C. So it can perform its multiple tasks efficiently and support overall bodily functions, D. So it can filter more blood Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a factory inside you 
that weighs about 1.4 kilograms and runs for 24 hours a day. This is your liver,
the heaviest organ in your body, and one of the most crucial. This industrious structure 
simultaneously acts as a storehouse, a manufacturing hub, and a processing plant. And each of these functions involve 
so many important subtasks that without the liver, 
our bodies would simply stop working. One of the liver's main functions 
is to filter the body's blood, which it receives in regular shipments 
from two sources: the hepatic artery 
delivers blood from the heart, while the hepatic portal vein 
brings it from the intestine. This double delivery 
fills the liver with nutrients, that it then sorts, processes and stores with the help of thousands 
of tiny internal processing plants, known as lobules. Both blood flows also deliver the oxygen 
that the liver needs to function. The blood that is received 
from the intestine contains carbohydrates, fats, and vitamins and other nutrients 
dissolved in it from the food you've consumed. These must be processed in different ways. In the case of carbohydrates, the liver breaks them down 
and converts them into sugars for the body to use as energy 
when the filtered blood is sent back out. Sometimes the body 
has leftovers of nutrients that it doesn't immediately require. When that happens, 
the liver holds some back, and stacks them in its storage facility. This facility works like a pantry for future cases when the body 
might be in need of nutrients. But the blood flowing into the liver
isn't always full of good things. It also contains toxins
and byproducts that the body can't use. And the liver monitors these strictly. When it spots
a useless or toxic substance, it either converts it into a product 
that can't hurt the body or isolates it and whisks it away, channeling it through 
the kidneys and intestine to be excreted. Of course, we wouldn't consider 
the liver a factory if it didn't also manufacture things. This organ makes everything 
from various blood plasma proteins that transport fatty acids 
and help form blood clots, to the cholesterol 
that helps the body create hormones. It also makes vitamin D
and substances that help digestion. But one of its most vital products 
is bile. Like an eco-friendly treatment plant, the liver uses cells called hepatocytes to convert toxic waste products 
into this bitter greenish liquid. As it's produced, bile is funneled 
into a small container below the liver, called the gallbladder, before being trickled into the intestine to help break down fats, destroy microbes,
and neutralize extra stomach acid. Bile also helps carry other toxins 
and byproducts from the liver out of the body. So as you can see, the liver is an extremely efficient 
industrial site, performing multiple tasks 
that support each other. But such a complex system 
needs to be kept running smoothly by keeping it healthy and not overloading it 
with more toxins than it can handle. This is one factory 
we simply can't afford to shut down.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is in the blood when it enters the liver?
Options: A. Just toxins, B. Only sugars and fats, C. Some oxygen but little else, D. Carbohydrates, vitamins, fats, and a range of other nutrients
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 24, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The onset of cancer usually begins as
a solitary tumor in a specific area of the body. If the tumor is not removed, cancer has the ability to 
spread to nearby organs, as well as places far away
from the origin, such as the brain. So how does cancer move to new areas, and why are some organs more likely
to get infected than others? The process of cancer spreading across the
body is known as metastasis. It begins when cancer cells from an initial
tumor invade nearby normal tissue. As the cells proliferate, they spread via one of the three 
common routes of metastasis: transcoelomic, lymphatic, 
or hematogenous spread. In transcoelomic spread, malignant cells
penetrate the covering surfaces of cavities in our body. These surfaces are known as 
peritoneum and serve as walls to segment 
the body cavity. Malignant cells in ovarian cancer, 
for example, spread through peritoneum, 
which connects the ovary to the liver, resulting in metastasis on 
the liver surface. Next, cancerous cells invade blood vessels
when they undergo hematogenous spread. As there are blood vessels almost 
everywhere in the body, malignant cells utilize this to reach
more distant parts of the body. Finally, lymphatic spread occurs
when the cancer invades the lymph nodes, and travels to other parts of the body
via the lymphatic system. As this system drains many
parts of the body, it also provides a large network
for the cancer. In addition, the lymphatic vessels empty
into the blood circulation, allowing the malignant cells to undergo
hematogenous spread. Once at a new site, the cells once again
undergo proliferation, and form small tumors known as
micrometastases. These small tumors then grow 
into full-fledged tumors, and complete the metastatic process. Different cancers have been known to have
specific sites of metastasis. For example, prostate cancer commonly
metastasizes to the bone, while colon cancer metastasizes 
to the liver. Various theories have been proposed to
explain the migration pattern of malignant cells. Of particular interest are 
two conflicting theories. Stephen Paget, an English surgeon, came up with the seed and soil
theory of metastasis. The seed and soil theory stated that
cancer cells die easily in the wrong microenvironment, hence they only metastasize to a location
with similar characteristics. However, James Ewing, the first professor
of pathology at Cornell University, challenged the seed and soil theory, and proposed that the site of metastasis
was determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels
which drain the primary tumor. Patients with primary tumors that were
drained by vessels leading to the lung would eventually develop lung metastases. Today, we know that both theories contain
valuable truths. Yet the full stories of metastasis is much
more complicated than either of the two proposed theories. Factors like the cancer cell's properties, and the effectiveness of the immune system
in eliminating the cancer cells, also play a role in determining
the success of metastasis. Unfortunately, many questions about 
metastasis remain unanswered until today. Understanding the exact mechanism holds
an important key to finding a cure for
advanced stage cancers. By studying both the genetic and
environmental factors, which contribute to successful metastasis, we can pinpoint ways to shut down
the process. The war against cancer is 
a constant struggle, and scientists are hard at work developing
new methods against metastasis. Of recent interest is immunotherapy, a modality which involves harnessing the
power of the immune system to destroy the migrating cells. This can be done in different ways, such as training immune cells to recognize
cancerous cells via vaccines. The growth and activity
of the immune cells can also be stimulated by injecting
man-made interleukins, chemicals which are usually secreted by
the immune cells of the body. These two treatments are only the
tip of the iceberg. With the collaborated research efforts of 
governments, companies and scientists, perhaps the process of metastasis will
be stopped for good.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is not a route where cancer cells can metastasize?
Options: A. Transcoelomic, B. Lymphatic, C. Transdermal, D. Haematogenous
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the process of cancer spreading across the body known as? Options: A. Transcoelomic spread, B. Lymphatic spread, C. Hematogenous spread, D. Metastasis Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following is NOT one of the common routes of metastasis? Options: A. Transcoelomic spread, B. Lymphatic spread, C. Hematogenous spread, D. Epithelial spread Correct Option: None
Question 3: In transcoelomic spread, malignant cells penetrate the covering surfaces of cavities in the body, known as: Options: A. Peritoneum, B. Epithelium, C. Connective tissue, D. Lymph nodes Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which type of cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver? Options: A. Prostate cancer, B. Colon cancer, C. Ovarian cancer, D. Lung cancer Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to the seed and soil theory of metastasis, cancer cells: Options: A. Can metastasize to any location in the body, B. Only metastasize to locations with similar characteristics, C. Die easily in the right microenvironment, D. Are unaffected by the microenvironment Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who proposed the theory that the site of metastasis is determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels which drain the primary tumor? Options: A. Stephen Paget, B. James Ewing, C. Albert Einstein, D. Louis Pasteur Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the small tumors that form at a new site after cancer cells undergo proliferation? Options: A. Micrometastases, B. Macrometastases, C. Metastatic tumors, D. Cancerous growths Correct Option: None
Question 8: Which of the following is a factor that plays a role in determining the success of metastasis? Options: A. The cancer cell's properties, B. The effectiveness of the immune system, C. The location of the primary tumor, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the name of the modality that involves harnessing the power of the immune system to destroy migrating cancer cells? Options: A. Immunotherapy, B. Chemotherapy, C. Radiation therapy, D. Surgery Correct Option: None
Question 10: How can the growth and activity of immune cells be stimulated to fight cancer? Options: A. By injecting man-made interleukins, B. By training immune cells to recognize cancerous cells via vaccines, C. By using antibiotics, D. By reducing inflammation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the options in Question 2 do not exactly match the options in the ground truth MCQ, the intent of the question is the same, which is to identify a route that is NOT one of the common routes of metastasis. 

In the ground truth MCQ, the correct answer is "Transdermal", which is not a common route of metastasis. In Question 2, the correct answer would be "Epithelial spread", which is also not a common route of metastasis mentioned in the transcript. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 24, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:

a solitary tumor in a specific area of the body. If the tumor is not removed, cancer has the ability to

governments, companies and scientists, perhaps the process of metastasis will
be stopped for good.

Options: A. Transcoelomic, B. Lymphatic, C. Transdermal, D. Respiratory
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 24, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The onset of cancer usually begins as
a solitary tumor in a specific area of the body. If the tumor is not removed, cancer has the ability to 
spread to nearby organs, as well as places far away
from the origin, such as the brain. So how does cancer move to new areas, and why are some organs more likely
to get infected than others? The process of cancer spreading across the
body is known as metastasis. It begins when cancer cells from an initial
tumor invade nearby normal tissue. As the cells proliferate, they spread via one of the three 
common routes of metastasis: transcoelomic, lymphatic, 
or hematogenous spread. In transcoelomic spread, malignant cells
penetrate the covering surfaces of cavities in our body. These surfaces are known as 
peritoneum and serve as walls to segment 
the body cavity. Malignant cells in ovarian cancer, 
for example, spread through peritoneum, 
which connects the ovary to the liver, resulting in metastasis on 
the liver surface. Next, cancerous cells invade blood vessels
when they undergo hematogenous spread. As there are blood vessels almost 
everywhere in the body, malignant cells utilize this to reach
more distant parts of the body. Finally, lymphatic spread occurs
when the cancer invades the lymph nodes, and travels to other parts of the body
via the lymphatic system. As this system drains many
parts of the body, it also provides a large network
for the cancer. In addition, the lymphatic vessels empty
into the blood circulation, allowing the malignant cells to undergo
hematogenous spread. Once at a new site, the cells once again
undergo proliferation, and form small tumors known as
micrometastases. These small tumors then grow 
into full-fledged tumors, and complete the metastatic process. Different cancers have been known to have
specific sites of metastasis. For example, prostate cancer commonly
metastasizes to the bone, while colon cancer metastasizes 
to the liver. Various theories have been proposed to
explain the migration pattern of malignant cells. Of particular interest are 
two conflicting theories. Stephen Paget, an English surgeon, came up with the seed and soil
theory of metastasis. The seed and soil theory stated that
cancer cells die easily in the wrong microenvironment, hence they only metastasize to a location
with similar characteristics. However, James Ewing, the first professor
of pathology at Cornell University, challenged the seed and soil theory, and proposed that the site of metastasis
was determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels
which drain the primary tumor. Patients with primary tumors that were
drained by vessels leading to the lung would eventually develop lung metastases. Today, we know that both theories contain
valuable truths. Yet the full stories of metastasis is much
more complicated than either of the two proposed theories. Factors like the cancer cell's properties, and the effectiveness of the immune system
in eliminating the cancer cells, also play a role in determining
the success of metastasis. Unfortunately, many questions about 
metastasis remain unanswered until today. Understanding the exact mechanism holds
an important key to finding a cure for
advanced stage cancers. By studying both the genetic and
environmental factors, which contribute to successful metastasis, we can pinpoint ways to shut down
the process. The war against cancer is 
a constant struggle, and scientists are hard at work developing
new methods against metastasis. Of recent interest is immunotherapy, a modality which involves harnessing the
power of the immune system to destroy the migrating cells. This can be done in different ways, such as training immune cells to recognize
cancerous cells via vaccines. The growth and activity
of the immune cells can also be stimulated by injecting
man-made interleukins, chemicals which are usually secreted by
the immune cells of the body. These two treatments are only the
tip of the iceberg. With the collaborated research efforts of 
governments, companies and scientists, perhaps the process of metastasis will
be stopped for good.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Stephen Paget, an English neurosurgeon, was famous for which of the theories for metastasis?
Options: A. Seed and soil theory, B. Seed and plant theory, C. Soil and plant theory, D. Anatomical drainage theory
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the process of cancer spreading across the body known as? Options: A. Transcoelomic spread, B. Lymphatic spread, C. Hematogenous spread, D. Metastasis Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following is NOT one of the common routes of metastasis? Options: A. Transcoelomic spread, B. Lymphatic spread, C. Hematogenous spread, D. Epithelial spread Correct Option: None
Question 3: In transcoelomic spread, malignant cells penetrate the covering surfaces of cavities in the body, known as: Options: A. Peritoneum, B. Epithelium, C. Connective tissue, D. Lymph nodes Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which type of cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver? Options: A. Prostate cancer, B. Colon cancer, C. Ovarian cancer, D. Lung cancer Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to the seed and soil theory of metastasis, cancer cells: Options: A. Can metastasize to any location in the body, B. Only metastasize to locations with similar characteristics, C. Die easily in the right microenvironment, D. Are unaffected by the microenvironment Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who proposed the theory that the site of metastasis is determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels which drain the primary tumor? Options: A. Stephen Paget, B. James Ewing, C. Albert Einstein, D. Louis Pasteur Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the small tumors that form at a new site after cancer cells undergo proliferation? Options: A. Micrometastases, B. Macrometastases, C. Metastatic tumors, D. Cancerous growths Correct Option: None
Question 8: Which of the following is a factor that plays a role in determining the success of metastasis? Options: A. The cancer cell's properties, B. The effectiveness of the immune system, C. The location of the primary tumor, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the name of the modality that involves harnessing the power of the immune system to destroy migrating cancer cells? Options: A. Immunotherapy, B. Chemotherapy, C. Radiation therapy, D. Surgery Correct Option: None
Question 10: How can the growth and activity of immune cells be stimulated to fight cancer? Options: A. By injecting man-made interleukins, B. By training immune cells to recognize cancerous cells via vaccines, C. By using antibiotics, D. By reducing inflammation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 24, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The onset of cancer usually begins as
a solitary tumor in a specific area of the body. If the tumor is not removed, cancer has the ability to 
spread to nearby organs, as well as places far away
from the origin, such as the brain. So how does cancer move to new areas, and why are some organs more likely
to get infected than others? The process of cancer spreading across the
body is known as metastasis. It begins when cancer cells from an initial
tumor invade nearby normal tissue. As the cells proliferate, they spread via one of the three 
common routes of metastasis: transcoelomic, lymphatic, 
or hematogenous spread. In transcoelomic spread, malignant cells
penetrate the covering surfaces of cavities in our body. These surfaces are known as 
peritoneum and serve as walls to segment 
the body cavity. Malignant cells in ovarian cancer, 
for example, spread through peritoneum, 
which connects the ovary to the liver, resulting in metastasis on 
the liver surface. Next, cancerous cells invade blood vessels
when they undergo hematogenous spread. As there are blood vessels almost 
everywhere in the body, malignant cells utilize this to reach
more distant parts of the body. Finally, lymphatic spread occurs
when the cancer invades the lymph nodes, and travels to other parts of the body
via the lymphatic system. As this system drains many
parts of the body, it also provides a large network
for the cancer. In addition, the lymphatic vessels empty
into the blood circulation, allowing the malignant cells to undergo
hematogenous spread. Once at a new site, the cells once again
undergo proliferation, and form small tumors known as
micrometastases. These small tumors then grow 
into full-fledged tumors, and complete the metastatic process. Different cancers have been known to have
specific sites of metastasis. For example, prostate cancer commonly
metastasizes to the bone, while colon cancer metastasizes 
to the liver. Various theories have been proposed to
explain the migration pattern of malignant cells. Of particular interest are 
two conflicting theories. Stephen Paget, an English surgeon, came up with the seed and soil
theory of metastasis. The seed and soil theory stated that
cancer cells die easily in the wrong microenvironment, hence they only metastasize to a location
with similar characteristics. However, James Ewing, the first professor
of pathology at Cornell University, challenged the seed and soil theory, and proposed that the site of metastasis
was determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels
which drain the primary tumor. Patients with primary tumors that were
drained by vessels leading to the lung would eventually develop lung metastases. Today, we know that both theories contain
valuable truths. Yet the full stories of metastasis is much
more complicated than either of the two proposed theories. Factors like the cancer cell's properties, and the effectiveness of the immune system
in eliminating the cancer cells, also play a role in determining
the success of metastasis. Unfortunately, many questions about 
metastasis remain unanswered until today. Understanding the exact mechanism holds
an important key to finding a cure for
advanced stage cancers. By studying both the genetic and
environmental factors, which contribute to successful metastasis, we can pinpoint ways to shut down
the process. The war against cancer is 
a constant struggle, and scientists are hard at work developing
new methods against metastasis. Of recent interest is immunotherapy, a modality which involves harnessing the
power of the immune system to destroy the migrating cells. This can be done in different ways, such as training immune cells to recognize
cancerous cells via vaccines. The growth and activity
of the immune cells can also be stimulated by injecting
man-made interleukins, chemicals which are usually secreted by
the immune cells of the body. These two treatments are only the
tip of the iceberg. With the collaborated research efforts of 
governments, companies and scientists, perhaps the process of metastasis will
be stopped for good.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following theories explains metastasis completely?
Options: A. Seed and soil theory, B. Anatomical drainage theory, C. Neither A nor B, D. Both A and B. However, metastasis is still not yet fully understood
Correct Option: D

Question 1: What is the process of cancer spreading across the body known as? Options: A. Transcoelomic spread, B. Lymphatic spread, C. Hematogenous spread, D. Metastasis Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which of the following is NOT one of the common routes of metastasis? Options: A. Transcoelomic spread, B. Lymphatic spread, C. Hematogenous spread, D. Epithelial spread Correct Option: None
Question 3: In transcoelomic spread, malignant cells penetrate the covering surfaces of cavities in the body, known as: Options: A. Peritoneum, B. Epithelium, C. Connective tissue, D. Lymph nodes Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which type of cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver? Options: A. Prostate cancer, B. Colon cancer, C. Ovarian cancer, D. Lung cancer Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to the seed and soil theory of metastasis, cancer cells: Options: A. Can metastasize to any location in the body, B. Only metastasize to locations with similar characteristics, C. Die easily in the right microenvironment, D. Are unaffected by the microenvironment Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who proposed the theory that the site of metastasis is determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels which drain the primary tumor? Options: A. Stephen Paget, B. James Ewing, C. Albert Einstein, D. Louis Pasteur Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the small tumors that form at a new site after cancer cells undergo proliferation? Options: A. Micrometastases, B. Macrometastases, C. Metastatic tumors, D. Cancerous growths Correct Option: None
Question 8: Which of the following is a factor that plays a role in determining the success of metastasis? Options: A. The cancer cell's properties, B. The effectiveness of the immune system, C. The location of the primary tumor, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the name of the modality that involves harnessing the power of the immune system to destroy migrating cancer cells? Options: A. Immunotherapy, B. Chemotherapy, C. Radiation therapy, D. Surgery Correct Option: None
Question 10: How can the growth and activity of immune cells be stimulated to fight cancer? Options: A. By injecting man-made interleukins, B. By training immune cells to recognize cancerous cells via vaccines, C. By using antibiotics, D. By reducing inflammation Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can suggest that the generated MCQs do not cover the same topic as the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the theories that explain metastasis completely. The closest generated MCQs that discuss theories of metastasis are:

- Question 6: Who proposed the theory that the site of metastasis is determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels which drain the primary tumor? Options: A. Stephen Paget, B. James Ewing, C. Albert Einstein, D. Louis Pasteur

spread to nearby organs, as well as places far away
from the origin, such as the brain. So how does cancer move to new areas, and why are some organs more likely

was determined by the location of the vascular and lymphatic channels
which drain the primary tumor. Patients with primary tumors that were
drained by vessels leading to the lung would eventually develop lung metastases. Today, we know that both theories contain
valuable truths. Yet the full stories of metastasis is much
more complicated than either of the two proposed theories. Factors like the cancer cell's properties, and the effectiveness of the immune system
in eliminating the cancer cells, also play a role in determining
the success of metastasis. Unfortunately, many questions about

an important key to finding a cure for

the process. The war against cancer is 
a constant struggle, and scientists are hard at work developing

power of the immune system to destroy the migrating cells. This can be done in different ways, such as training immune cells to recognize
cancerous cells via vaccines. The growth and activity
of the immune cells can also be stimulated by injecting
man-made interleukins, chemicals which are usually secreted by
the immune cells of the body. These two treatments are only the
tip of the iceberg. With the collaborated research efforts of 
governments, companies and scientists, perhaps the process of metastasis will
be stopped for good.

Question: Which of the following is not a type of immunotherapy?
Options: A. Training the immune cells to recognize cancer cells, B. Injecting man-made interleukins to stimulate growth and activity of immune cells, C. Training red blood cells to recognize cancer cells, D. Maturing white blood cells outside the body before transplanting them back into the body
Correct Option: C

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 2, Matched Generated Question 2
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
"Hi, Bob." "Morning, Kelly. The tulips looks great." Have you ever wondered
how your dog experiences the world? Here's what she sees. Not terribly interesting. But what she smells,
that's a totally different story. And it begins at her wonderfully 
developed nose. As your dog catches 
the first hints of fresh air, her nose's moist, spongy outside helps
capture any scents the breeze carries. The ability to smell 
separately with each nostril, smelling in stereo, helps to determine the direction 
of the smell's source so that within the first 
few moments of sniffing, the dog starts to become aware of not
just what kind of things are out there but also where they're located. As air enters the nose, a small fold of tissue 
divides it into two separate folds, one for breathing 
and one just for smelling. This second airflow enters a region filled with highly specialized 
olfactory receptor cells, several hundred millions of them,
compaired to our five million. And unlike our clumsy way of breathing 
in and out through the same passage, dogs exhale through slits 
at the side of their nose, creating swirls of air that help
draw in new odor molecules and allow odor concentration to build up
over mulitple sniffs. But all that impressive nasal architecture
wouldn't be much help without something to process the loads
of information the nose scoops up. And it turns out that the olfactory system
dedicated to proessing smells takes up many times more relative
brain area in dogs than in humans. All of this allows dogs to distinguish and remember a staggering 
variety of specific scents at concentrations up to 100 million times
less than what our noses can detect. If you can smell a spritz of perfume
in a small room, a dog would have no trouble smelling it
in an enclosed stadium and distinguishing its ingredients,
to boot. And everything in the street,
every passing person or car, any contents of the neighbor's trash, each type of tree, and all the birds and insects in it has a distinct odor profile telling
your dog what it is, where it is, and which direction it's moving in. Besides being much 
more powerful than ours, a dog's sense of smell can pick up things
that can't even be seen at all. A whole separate olfactory system, called the vomeronasal organ,
above the roof of the mouth, detects the hormones all animals,
Including humans, naturally release. It lets dogs identify potential mates, or distinguish between friendly 
and hostile animals. It alerts them to our various 
emotional states, and it can even tell them 
when someone is pregnant or sick. Because olfaction is more primal 
than other senses, bypassing the thalamus to connect
directly to the brain structures involving emotion and instinct, we might even say a dog's perception 
is more immediate and visceral than ours. But the most amazing thing about 
your dog's nose is that it can traverse time. The past appears in tracks 
left by passersby, and by the warmth 
of a recently parked car where the residue of where you've been
and what you've done recently. Landmarks like fire hydrants and trees are aromatic bulletin boards 
carrying messages of who's been by, what they've been eating, and how they're feeling. And the future is in the breeze, alerting them to something or someone
approaching long before you see them. Where we see and hear something
at a single moment, a dog smells an entire story
from start to finish. In some of the best examples
of canine-human collaboration, dogs help us by sharing
and reacting to those stories. They can respond with kindness
to people in distress, or with aggression to threats because stress and anger 
manifest as a cloud of hormones recognizable to the dog's nose. With the proper training, they can even alert us 
to invisible threats ranging from bombs to cancer. As it turns out, humanity's best friend is not one who experiences 
the same things we do, but one whose incredible nose reveals 
a whole other world beyond our eyes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Dogs have how many specialized olfactory receptor cells?
Options: A. 5 million, B. 300 million, C. 7 million, D. Less than 100
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: How many olfactory receptor cells do dogs have compared to humans?
Options: A. Fewer than humans, B. The same number as humans, C. Several hundred million, compared to humans' five million, D. Only a few thousand
Correct Option: None

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Dogs have how many specialized olfactory receptor cells?
Options: A. 5 million, B. 300 million, C. 7 million, D. Less than 100
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: How many olfactory receptor cells do dogs have compared to humans?
Options: A. Fewer than humans, B. The same number as humans, C. Several hundred million, compared to humans' five million, D. Only a few thousand
Correct Option: None

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.9000 (The generated question is closely related to the ground truth question, but it adds a comparison to humans that is not present in the ground truth question.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 0.8000 (The correct answer option in the generated question is not explicitly stated, but option C provides the correct information. However, it does not exactly match the ground truth answer.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.7000 (The distractors in the generated question are somewhat plausible, but option A is unlikely, and option D is not a reasonable estimate.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (The generated question and options are clear and understandable, but the correct answer is not explicitly stated.)
- Total Score: 0.8250

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 3, Matched Generated Question 1
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
"Hi, Bob." "Morning, Kelly. The tulips looks great." Have you ever wondered
how your dog experiences the world? Here's what she sees. Not terribly interesting. But what she smells,

developed nose. As your dog catches

a whole other world beyond our eyes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Dogs can smell separately with each nostril. This is an advantage. Why? Choose the answers from the following list: A. They can exhale out one nostril and inhale in the other B. They can determine what is out there C. It allows them to keep their nose moist and spongy D. They can determine the location of the smell
Options: A. All of the above, B. B only, C. A and C, D. B and D
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is unique about the way dogs smell compared to humans?
Options: A. They can only smell with one nostril at a time, B. They can only detect a limited range of scents, C. They can smell separately with each nostril, allowing them to determine the direction of the smell's source, D. They can only detect strong odors
Correct Option: None

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Dogs can smell separately with each nostril. This is an advantage. Why? Choose the answers from the following list: A. They can exhale out one nostril and inhale in the other B. They can determine what is out there C. It allows them to keep their nose moist and spongy D. They can determine the location of the smell
Options: A. All of the above, B. B only, C. A and C, D. B and D
Correct Option: D

Options: A. They can only smell with one nostril at a time, B. They can only detect a limited range of scents, C. They can smell separately with each nostril, allowing them to determine the direction of the smell's source, D. They can only detect strong odors
Correct Option: None

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 4, Matched Generated Question 7
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
"Hi, Bob." "Morning, Kelly. The tulips looks great." Have you ever wondered
how your dog experiences the world? Here's what she sees. Not terribly interesting. But what she smells,
that's a totally different story. And it begins at her wonderfully 
developed nose. As your dog catches 
the first hints of fresh air, her nose's moist, spongy outside helps
capture any scents the breeze carries. The ability to smell 
separately with each nostril, smelling in stereo, helps to determine the direction 
of the smell's source so that within the first 
few moments of sniffing, the dog starts to become aware of not
just what kind of things are out there but also where they're located. As air enters the nose, a small fold of tissue 
divides it into two separate folds, one for breathing 
and one just for smelling. This second airflow enters a region filled with highly specialized 
olfactory receptor cells, several hundred millions of them,
compaired to our five million. And unlike our clumsy way of breathing 
in and out through the same passage, dogs exhale through slits 
at the side of their nose, creating swirls of air that help
draw in new odor molecules and allow odor concentration to build up
over mulitple sniffs. But all that impressive nasal architecture
wouldn't be much help without something to process the loads
of information the nose scoops up. And it turns out that the olfactory system
dedicated to proessing smells takes up many times more relative
brain area in dogs than in humans. All of this allows dogs to distinguish and remember a staggering 
variety of specific scents at concentrations up to 100 million times
less than what our noses can detect. If you can smell a spritz of perfume
in a small room, a dog would have no trouble smelling it
in an enclosed stadium and distinguishing its ingredients,
to boot. And everything in the street,
every passing person or car, any contents of the neighbor's trash, each type of tree, and all the birds and insects in it has a distinct odor profile telling
your dog what it is, where it is, and which direction it's moving in. Besides being much 
more powerful than ours, a dog's sense of smell can pick up things
that can't even be seen at all. A whole separate olfactory system, called the vomeronasal organ,
above the roof of the mouth, detects the hormones all animals,
Including humans, naturally release. It lets dogs identify potential mates, or distinguish between friendly 
and hostile animals. It alerts them to our various 
emotional states, and it can even tell them 
when someone is pregnant or sick. Because olfaction is more primal 
than other senses, bypassing the thalamus to connect
directly to the brain structures involving emotion and instinct, we might even say a dog's perception 
is more immediate and visceral than ours. But the most amazing thing about 
your dog's nose is that it can traverse time. The past appears in tracks 
left by passersby, and by the warmth 
of a recently parked car where the residue of where you've been
and what you've done recently. Landmarks like fire hydrants and trees are aromatic bulletin boards 
carrying messages of who's been by, what they've been eating, and how they're feeling. And the future is in the breeze, alerting them to something or someone
approaching long before you see them. Where we see and hear something
at a single moment, a dog smells an entire story
from start to finish. In some of the best examples
of canine-human collaboration, dogs help us by sharing
and reacting to those stories. They can respond with kindness
to people in distress, or with aggression to threats because stress and anger 
manifest as a cloud of hormones recognizable to the dog's nose. With the proper training, they can even alert us 
to invisible threats ranging from bombs to cancer. As it turns out, humanity's best friend is not one who experiences 
the same things we do, but one whose incredible nose reveals 
a whole other world beyond our eyes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Olfaction bypasses the thalamus and goes directly to the brain, making the dog's senses _____
Options: A. Visceral and more immediate, B. Slower and more time consuming, C. Unable to detect certain odors, D. Only able to detect food sources
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is unique about the way a dog's brain processes olfactory information?
Options: A. It is processed in the same way as visual information, B. It is processed in the same way as auditory information, C. It bypasses the thalamus and connects directly to brain structures involving emotion and instinct, D. It is processed in a slower and more deliberate manner
Correct Option: None

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:

2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

**Generated MCQ**:

Options: A. It is processed in the same way as visual information, B. It is processed in the same way as auditory information, C. It bypasses the thalamus and connects directly to brain structures involving emotion and instinct, D. It is processed in a slower and more deliberate manner

**Scores**:

**Transcript**:
"Hi, Bob." "Morning, Kelly. The tulips looks great." Have you ever wondered
how your dog experiences the world? Here's what she sees. Not terribly interesting. But what she smells,
that's a totally different story. And it begins at her wonderfully 
developed nose. As your dog catches 
the first hints of fresh air, her nose's moist, spongy outside helps
capture any scents the breeze carries. The ability to smell 
separately with each nostril, smelling in stereo, helps to determine the direction 
of the smell's source so that within the first 
few moments of sniffing, the dog starts to become aware of not

divides it into two separate folds, one for breathing 
and one just for smelling. This second airflow enters a region filled with highly specialized 
olfactory receptor cells, several hundred millions of them,
compaired to our five million. And unlike our clumsy way of breathing 
in and out through the same passage, dogs exhale through slits 
at the side of their nose, creating swirls of air that help
draw in new odor molecules and allow odor concentration to build up
over mulitple sniffs. But all that impressive nasal architecture
wouldn't be much help without something to process the loads
of information the nose scoops up. And it turns out that the olfactory system
dedicated to proessing smells takes up many times more relative
brain area in dogs than in humans. All of this allows dogs to distinguish and remember a staggering 
variety of specific scents at concentrations up to 100 million times
less than what our noses can detect. If you can smell a spritz of perfume
